Posts.Content: Hi sarah316 i was diagnosed September and have 2 children. The worst time for me was the waiting - once i had lumpectomy i was much better although still a bit up and down which is to be expected.  I didnt need chemo and my radiotherapy planning appt is tomorrow. We celebrated each milestone / each scan / each result as a step closer to the goal. The early few weeks I wondered whether i would ever be ‘normal’ again and longed for my old life back.  I feel good again now (my new normal i guess) and can certainly enjoy life once more.  Dont be hard on yourself you are probably still in shock (to be expected) and will be wondering how you will get through this - for me what worked was trying to keep a routine and doing certain things at certain times. I hid from the world for the first month at least as couldnt bear the thought of people feeling sorry for me.  As i said i cant comment on the chemo but the lovely people here will be able to help you with that. Im very happy to answer any questions about my experiences.  Thinking of you xx

Posts.Content: I went through all those thoughts too. The why me,  etc etc.  my mum had breast cancer 15 years ago she is now in her 70’s and had no further issues - my lump ‘type’ was exactly the same as hers and we have had the same consultant too. That gives me confidence.  I sent an email to people i had avoided and was very strong about the fact that no one should memtion ‘it’ unless I mentioned it first. This helped me enormously as everything was on my terms and I felt more in control.  Friends and acquaintances were 110% following my instructions. Work was a little difficult as i manage people and i kept thinking they are all talking about me and it took some time to rebuild my confidence. I struggled last Tuesday no idea why so i just told my boss i could only work half a day - again i felt in control snd this helps me.  Do you work? Would it help to ‘normalise’ things?  Xx

Posts.Content: Thankyou for your lovely message and i am so sorry to hear your mum is going through it. My mum was diagnosed age 56 and is now 70 and perfectly fine and healthy.  I managed to sleep last night through sheer exhaustion and got up early and did housework to be normal. Had proper meltdown last night but my husband and daughters put me back together again.  Met with my consultant this evening and my biopsy showed stage 1 which is the best it could have been. Cant believe I celebrated with a sherry after being told i have stage 1 BC. But it could have been worse.  I have an MRI scan next week and an appt to plan course of action on Wednesday but it is likely ‘quick op’ (my consultants words) followrd by hormone tablets and some radiotherapy.  Consultant doesnt seem too concerned and is sure i will be anle to go on holiday in october being fit and well.  What a few days......sending lots of love your way for your mum and you and let us know how it all goes xx

Posts.Title: Morning after diagnosis.....

Posts.Content: Great news with the mammogram and clinical assessment.  My lump didn’t show on the mammogram despite it being IDC but did on the ultrasound. I was private so had an MRI prior to lumpectomy surgery as ‘routine’. The Mri showed up 2 further areas of concern. One couldnt he found on ultrasound (1mm) and the other 3mm concern turned out to be Fibroadenoma.  After doing lots of reading it seems that Mri are infamous for showing false positives. My consultant said most occasions the mri will find something and in most occasions it turns out to be nothing of concern.  I understand how you feel entirely - i have an MRI scheduled for march next year as part of my 6 monthly follow up - this will pick up everything hopefully but i will need to be prepared for this and remind myself of the false positive rate.  Good luck x
Posts.Title: One year on - mamogram and clinical assessment

Posts.Content: Hi Kirsteen78 i was diagnosed last September and since then have had to go back to the consultant on 3 separate occasions as i have found further lumps. These turned out to be cysts which i was told are probably caused by the tamoxifen. The smallest was 1mm, and the largest was 8mm. Im so ‘good’ at finding the tiniest of lumps my consultant was shocked that i found them so small mind you i am very slim with only a b cup.  Hope all goes well and the anxiety is just about bearable until you get seen. So hard isn’t it.  Xx
